name: INTRO TO LAW & LEG PROC

values.comments:
LGST 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.

Students agreed that the course material was interesting and engaging. Some students spoke particularly positively about the course, with several students declaring that it was the best course they had taken at Penn.

Students seemed to agree that Professor Nichols was very dedicated to student learning, describing how he “went out of his way to be accessible outside of class” and made sure every student understood the material. However, students were divided over his teaching style of “cold calling” students. Some students responded positively to his method of calling on students, describing it as “engaging” and a “classroom style that requires that every student come prepared to class.” On the other hand, many students felt that Professor Nichols was “abrasive,” “rough on the edges,” and even “mean.” One student described the “the trepidation of stepping into class everyday,” but then stated that he still enjoyed the class because he learned a lot.

Students agreed that it was important to complete the readings before class, because Professor Nichols could “cold call” on any student and question him or her about the readings. Since participation counted for 30% of class, students felt that it was important to adequately respond to Professor Nichols in-class questions.

The course examines law as an evolving social institution, focusing on the legal regulation of business. Specifically it considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. Furthermore, the course includes an in-depth examination of contract law. 

Students describe the class as “excellent” and “enjoyable” to learn. While the course can be tedious and confusing at times, the subject material is still interesting and worthwhile to learn. Some students commented this was one of the hardest classes they had ever taken, but the teacher was able to present the material in a clear way.

Students raved about Professor Marston. In fact, one student commented, “Professor Marston is simply one of the best teachers I have ever had.” Marston, being a lawyer herself, is an excellent resource for her students and her knowledge is extensive. Described as “fun” and “funny” Marston really does her best to make the class enjoyable. In order to tackle the difficult material, she provides great examples on her slides and is a good lecturer. 

Although this course is part of the Wharton core, many students recommend this class to any student, even if they are not a Legal Study major or minor. Some students commented the reading is extensive and you must truly understand the material, rather than just memorizing facts, for the exams. A student must be willing to put in effort during the course. The course gives a foundation for law for any student as Penn.

An in-depth examination of contract law is included. Students almost uniformly described the lectures as interesting, engaging, and, for the most part, worth showing up for even at 9:00 in the morning. One student wished that Professor Miller would “outline his lectures a little more.” Professor Miller received overwhelmingly positive comments from students, who praised him as “wonderful,” “spectacular,” “hilarious,” and, according to one reviewer, “one of the nicest, most approachable professors I have ever met.” 

While several students mentioned the difficulty of tests and grading, most agreed that the material was relevant, “fascinating,” and “a lot of fun.” As one student put it, “I think that all of the information I learned will be extremely valuable in my future at Penn and in society.”
